hedline.hl1: MP3 Jukebox Tries to Replace Just About Everything

abstract.p: DigMedia's new MusicStore tabletop digital audio jukebox plays CD's on built-in drive and can copy music from CD's into MP4 audio files and store them; comes with a companion portable MP3 player that weighs 3.5 ounces and can store near-CD-quality music; photo (M)

block.p: If you have not yet been swept up in the digital music explosion, either by choice or indifference, you pose a tempting target for an increasing group of companies determined to develop devices that will make you forget all about your old stereo system.

One of the latest variations on the theme is DigMedia's new MusicStore, a tabletop digital audio jukebox. Designed to be self-contained, MusicStore plays CD's on a built-in drive and delivers the sound through headphones.

If you have not yet been swept up in the digital music explosion, either by choice or indifference, you pose a tempting target for an increasing group of companies determined to develop devices that will make you forget all about your old stereo system.

One of the latest variations on the theme is DigMedia's new MusicStore, a tabletop digital audio jukebox. Designed to be self-contained, MusicStore plays CD's on a built-in drive and delivers the sound through headphones.

The device can also copy music from CD's into MP3 audio files and store them (about 200 CD's at FM quality) on its 5.4-gigabyte internal hard drive. It costs about $500, measures 12.8 inches by 6.5 inches by 2 inches and weighs 2.6 pounds.

In a novel development, the device comes with a companion portable MP3 player, called a SoulMate, that fits into a slot to pick up music files. The player weighs 3.5 ounces and is a dead ringer for a fancy cellular telephone.
The SoulMate, which can store less than an hour's worth of near-CD-quality music in its 48-megabyte memory, sells separately for about $100.
When the MusicStore is linked with included stereo cables to a standard amplifier of a home stereo system, it can play its digital music files through speakers.
The device may also be linked, by way of a U.S.B. line, to a personal computer so MP3 audio files on the PC's hard drive may be moved in and out of its memory.
The MusicStore comes with installation and music management software and a few preloaded tracks.
